problem: A 56.5-kg hiker starts at an elevation of 1270 m and climbs to the top of a 2660-m peak. (a) What is the hiker's change in potential energy? (b) What is the minimum work required of the hiker? (c) Can the actual work done be greater than this? Explain.

steps.explanation: Compute the elevation gain and apply ΔU = m g Δy.
The minimum work the hiker must do equals the increase in potential energy (ignoring losses).
Yes; real hikes involve inefficiencies (non-vertical paths, friction, metabolic costs), so actual work exceeds this ideal minimum.
steps.notations: W₍actual₎ ≥ W₍min₎ due to nonconservative forces
